title: School makes minor change to uniform – forcing parents to buy expensive replacement
text:

A large secondary school has decided to implement a small change to its uniform, and it could cost parents hundreds. 
Senior staff at Cheltenham Bournside, in Gloucestershire, has issued new guidelines about skirts and trousers. Both must now carry the school's emblem on the left hip. 
Parents are worried that the change will leave them out of pocket given that they'll now have to purchase the same clothing items for a second time. Those with more than one child attending will be especially affected. 
A letter to parents sent out on Friday reads: "Uniform is important to us in Bournside school because it allows our students to have a sense of pride and self-respect for the way that they present themselves. The change is minor (Photo: Gloucester Live WS) Read More Parents marry in hospice to share final special day with terminally ill son 
"We notice when people look smart and the way that we wear our uniform is a clear message to everyone that we care about ourselves in this manner. 
"To support this, following parent and staff consultation, we are introducing some changes to our school uniform. These will be compulsory from September 2017, although the new uniform items will available to buy from our school uniform suppliers 'Schooltogs' from April 10 and we encourage students to buy and wear these as soon as possible." 
The letter, which notes that the changes to the school uniforms are minor, also explains that parents who buy the new clothing between April 10-22 will be given a ten per cent discount. But the actual cost of the new uniform wasn't revealed.
